title: Can you solve the rogue AI riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of the game against the hostile artificial intelligence NIM?

options.label: B
options.text: To be the first to lower the water level to 0

options.label: C
options.text: To keep the water level constant

options.label: D
options.text: To make NIM skip a turn

options.text: The player can lower the water level by 1, 3, or 4 stories

options.label: B
options.text: The player can lower the water level by 1 story only

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To always raise the water level

options.label: C
options.text: By looking at the levels 2, 5, and 6 stories above it

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the pattern of losing levels in the game?

options.label: A
options.text: Multiples of 3 and two greater than multiples of 3

options.label: B
options.text: Multiples of 5 and two greater than multiples of 5

options.label: C
options.text: Multiples of 7 and two greater than multiples of 7

options.label: D
options.text: Multiples of 9 and two greater than multiples of 9

options.text: Because NIM will get bored and give up

options.text: Because NIM will make a mistake and lose

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: To lower the water level by 4 stories

options.label: D

options.text: It has no effect on the meniscus.

options.label: C
options.text: By using their shape to curve the water up and get pulled to the edge.

options.label: D
options.text: By using their tiny hairs to trap air bubbles.

options.label: C
options.text: Because gravity pushes them into the depressions under their feet.

multiple-choice.question: How do aquatic insects manage to climb the meniscus and get out of the water?

options.label: C
options.text: By arching their bodies and lifting their front and back ends to curve the water up.

options.label: D

Who was the first human launched into space by the United States?
In what year did China launch its first human into space?
What is the primary mission of SpaceX, according to Elon Musk?

options.label: B
options.text: To launch commercial satellites into space

options.label: D
options.text: To send humans to the International Space Station

multiple-choice.question: When was NASA created?
What is the name of the spacecraft that SpaceX intends to use for human space travel?
How does SpaceX primarily make money?

options.label: B
options.text: By sending commercial satellites into space

options.label: C
options.text: By launching supplies to the International Space Station

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated total revenue for SpaceX?
What is the name of NASA's planetary rover that was launched in 2011?
What is the primary difference between an astronaut and a cosmonaut?

options.label: A
options.text: Astronauts are trained for deep space missions, while cosmonauts are trained for low-Earth orbit missions

options.label: B
options.text: Astronauts are trained and certified through NASA, while cosmonauts are trained solely through Russia's space program

options.label: C
options.text: Astronauts are trained for manned space travel, while cosmonauts are trained for unmanned space travel

options.label: D
options.text: Astronauts are trained for spacewalks, while cosmonauts are not

title: Can we survive the sun's death?

multiple-choice.question: How old is the sun?
What will happen to the Earth's surface in about 1 billion years due to the sun's expansion?

options.label: A
options.text: It will freeze due to reduced heat

options.label: B
options.text: It will melt due to increased heat

options.label: D
options.text: It will become a desert due to reduced water

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the technique that can potentially save Earth from the sun's ultimate death?
According to Newton's law, what happens when a spacecraft uses a planet's gravity to speed up?

options.label: A
options.text: The planet speeds up and moves away from the spacecraft

options.label: B
options.text: The planet slows down and moves towards the spacecraft

options.label: C
options.text: The spacecraft slows down and moves away from the planet

options.label: D
options.text: The spacecraft and planet remain unchanged

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate mass of the object needed to move the Earth's orbit away from the sun within a billion years?
How often would an object need to encounter Earth to move its orbit within a billion years?
What is the name of the spacecraft that used Earth's gravity assist on October 9th, 2013?
What is the potential risk of using a large asteroid to move Earth's orbit?

options.label: A
options.text: Losing the moon and creating extreme weather patterns

options.label: B
options.text: Gaining a new moon and stabilizing the climate

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the Earth's spin and making days longer

options.label: D
options.text: Decreasing the Earth's spin and making days shorter

multiple-choice.question: What is the desired orbit of Earth to avoid the sun's ultimate death?
What is the potential outcome of moving Earth's orbit using a large asteroid?

options.label: A
options.text: Giving our descendants and the planet a few extra billion years

options.label: B
options.text: Reducing the Earth's lifespan by a few billion years

options.label: C
options.text: Having no effect on the Earth's lifespan

title: Why don’t poisonous animals poison themselves? - Rebecca D. Tarvin

multiple-choice.question: What did Charles Darwin find when he tore off old bark from a tree?
What is unique about the bombardier beetle's defense mechanism?

options.label: B
options.text: It spews poisonous liquid from glands in its abdomen

multiple-choice.question: How do bombardier beetles protect themselves from their own poisonous secretions?

options.label: A
options.text: By evolving resistance to the poison

options.label: B
options.text: By storing the poison ingredients in separate chambers

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the chemical that poison dart frogs accumulate from consuming small arthropods?
How do poison dart frogs prevent themselves from being poisoned by their own toxins?

options.label: A
options.text: By evolving resistance to the toxins

options.label: B
options.text: By changing the shape of the molecular target of the toxin

options.label: C
options.text: By storing the toxins in separate chambers

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an animal that has evolved resistance to the toxins of its prey?
What is the result of the evolutionary arms race between toxic animals and their predators?

options.label: A
options.text: The genes providing the highest resistance and toxicity will be passed on in greatest quantities to the next generations

options.label: B
options.text: The genes providing the lowest resistance and toxicity will be passed on in greatest quantities to the next generations

options.label: C
options.text: The predators will eventually become extinct

options.label: D
options.text: The prey will eventually become extinct

multiple-choice.question: How do sea slugs prevent the activation of jellyfish nematocysts?

options.label: B
options.text: By storing the nematocysts in separate chambers

options.label: C
options.text: By using compounds in their mucus

options.label: D
options.text: By evolving resistance to the nematocysts

multiple-choice.question: What is the mystery surrounding the toads that swallow bombardier beetles?

options.label: B
options.text: How they survive the caustic spray

options.label: D
options.text: How they evolve resistance to the beetles' toxins

multiple-choice.question: At what temperature is the caustic substance ejected by the bombardier beetle?

title: Can you solve the Mondrian squares riddle? - Gord Hamilton

multiple-choice.question: What inspired mathematicians to create a two-fold challenge of covering a square canvas with non-overlapping rectangles?

options.label: A
options.text: Dutch artist Vincent van Gogh's paintings

options.label: B
options.text: Dutch artist Piet Mondrian's abstract, rectangular paintings

options.label: C
options.text: German artist Paul Klee's abstract paintings

options.label: D
options.text: Spanish artist Pablo Picasso's cubist paintings

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition for using rectangles to cover a square canvas in the challenge?

options.label: B
options.text: All rectangles must be unique, but can have the same area

options.label: C
options.text: All rectangles must be unique, and cannot have the same area or be rotations of each other

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of the challenge after covering the canvas with non-overlapping rectangles?

options.label: A
options.text: To maximize the area of the largest rectangle

options.label: B
options.text: To minimize the area of the smallest rectangle

options.label: C
options.text: To get as low a score as possible by subtracting the area of the smallest rectangle from the area of the largest rectangle

options.label: D
options.text: To make all rectangles have the same area

multiple-choice.question: What is the score obtained by dividing a 4x4 canvas into a 3x4 and a 1x4 rectangle?
How can the score of 8 be improved for a 4x4 canvas?

options.label: A
options.text: By dividing the 3x4 rectangle into a 3x3 and a 3x1 rectangle

options.label: B
options.text: By dividing the 1x4 rectangle into two 1x2 rectangles

options.label: C
options.text: By dividing the 3x4 rectangle into two 2x3 rectangles

options.label: D
options.text: By dividing the 1x4 rectangle into four 1x1 squares

multiple-choice.question: What is the score obtained by dividing an 8x8 canvas into a 5x8 and a 3x8 rectangle?
Why does dividing the largest rectangle into smaller rectangles not always lead to a better score?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it increases the range between the largest and smallest rectangles

options.label: B
options.text: Because it decreases the range between the largest and smallest rectangles

options.label: C
options.text: Because it makes all rectangles have the same area

options.label: D
options.text: Because it maximizes the area of the largest rectangle

multiple-choice.question: What is the total area of an 8x8 canvas that needs to be covered by rectangles?
What is the best score that can be obtained for an 8x8 canvas using the given method?
According to the transcript, what is the nature of finding the lowest possible scores for larger grids?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be done using a specific formula

options.label: B
options.text: It is more art than science and requires intuition

options.label: C
options.text: It is a straightforward process that requires no intuition

options.label: D
options.text: It is impossible to find the lowest possible scores for larger grids

title: Why do some people hate cilantro?

multiple-choice.question: What is the scientific name of the herb commonly known as cilantro?
Which country is the largest exporter of cilantro?

Which chromosome is associated with the sense of smell and contains the genes for several odor detectors?
What is the name of the gene thought to be responsible for detecting cilantro's odor-causing compounds?
What type of compounds are responsible for cilantro's primary odor-causing properties?
Which two compounds in the aldehyde group are responsible for cilantro's earthy, sweet, green aroma?
What is the characteristic taste associated with the (E)-2-Alkenals in cilantro?
According to the transcript, what is the current state of scientific understanding regarding the exact mechanism behind the soapy phenomenon in cilantro?

title: What do food expiration dates actually mean?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of Sell By, Best By, or Use By dates on food products?

options.label: B
options.text: To indicate food quality and flavor

options.label: C
options.text: To indicate the date of manufacture

options.label: D
options.text: To indicate the date of packaging

multiple-choice.question: What can affect a product's real expiration date?

options.label: B
options.text: Only the temperature of the fridge

options.label: C
options.text: Everything from the sanitation of the factory to the temperature of the fridge

options.label: D
options.text: Only the date on the label

multiple-choice.question: What can make produce become unsafe to eat?
What can mold produce that can harm humans?
How can the shelf life of produce be extended?

options.label: A
options.text: By storing it at room temperature

options.label: B
options.text: By storing it in the fridge

multiple-choice.question: What process is used to treat milk to kill bacteria?
What happens to milk when bacteria convert its sugars into lactic acid?
What is a sign that meat has gone bad?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of volatile organic compounds (VOCs)

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to meat when bacteria like Psuedomonas or Lactobacilli feast on its surface?
What should you do if you're uncertain whether a food has expired?

options.label: C
options.text: Play it safe and discard it

title: How I turn negative online comments into positive offline conversations

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's profession?
What was the title of the speaker's video series that edited down popular films to only the words spoken by people of color?
What is the term "beta" shorthand for in online lingo?
What is the term "cuck" short for?
How did the speaker initially respond to hate messages?

options.label: B
options.text: By screenshotting and making fun of their typos

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's unexpected coping mechanism for dealing with hate messages?

options.label: C
options.text: Clicking on the profile picture of the person who sent them and learning more about them

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's opening question when calling people who had sent hate messages?
What was the result of the speaker's conversation with Josh, who had written a hate message?

options.label: A
options.text: Josh apologized and took back his words

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker and Josh became friends

options.label: C
options.text: The conversation humanized them to each other

options.label: D
options.text: The conversation had no effect on either of them

multiple-choice.question: What is the title of the speaker's podcast?
What is the speaker's mantra for empathizing with people who disagree with him?

options.label: C
options.text: Empathy is a sign of weakness

options.label: D
options.text: Empathy is a sign of strength

title: How much of what you see is a hallucination? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: What condition did Rosalie, the elderly woman, develop, which caused her to hallucinate whole scenes in vivid color?
According to fMRI studies, which brain areas are activated by hallucinations in patients with Charles Bonnet Syndrome?

options.label: C
options.text: The same brain areas as sight

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the thin layer of grey matter that covers the entire cerebrum and processes information from each of our senses?
Why do scientists think the brain uses remembered images to compensate for the lack of new visual input in people with Charles Bonnet Syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the brain is trying to create a new sense

options.label: B
options.text: Because the brain is trying to forget past memories

options.label: C
options.text: Because Charles Bonnet Syndrome only occurs in people who had normal vision and then lost their sight

options.label: D
options.text: Because the brain is trying to process new information

multiple-choice.question: What is a common cause of hallucinations, in addition to sensory deprivation and psychiatric disorders?
Which substances are known to cause perceptual disturbances across all the senses?
What is the role of serotonin in the brain, according to the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: To integrate information from the eyes, nose, ears, and other sensory organs

multiple-choice.question: How do antipsychotic drugs relieve symptoms of schizophrenia?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing serotonin levels in the brain

options.label: B
options.text: By blocking the same serotonin receptors LSD and psilocybin bind to

options.label: C
options.text: By reducing dopamine levels in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: By increasing dopamine levels in the brain

multiple-choice.question: What can be learned by studying hallucinations, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: How our brains construct the world we see, hear, smell, and touch

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion that can be drawn from the study of hallucinations, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Hallucinations are a rare and unusual phenomenon

options.label: B
options.text: Hallucinations are a sign of mental illness

options.label: C
options.text: Hallucinatory experiences are much more closely tied to ordinary perception than we once thought

options.label: D
options.text: Hallucinations can be cured with medication

title: What can we learn from insect cribs?

multiple-choice.question: What term is given to organisms that live in multi-generational groups, cooperatively take care of their young, have a caste system, and have a division of labor?
Which of the following is a characteristic of a worker bee in a eusocial society?
Which order of insects includes bees, wasps, and ants, and is known for eusocial behavior?
What is the name of the ant scientist who developed the method of pouring molten aluminum into ant colonies to create detailed impressions of their underground homes?
What is the primary source of nutrition for carpenter ants?
What is the name of the tree that has evolved to co-exist with stinging ants in a mutually beneficial way?
Which species of ants uses silk produced by larvae to stitch together leaves to build their nests?
What is the name of the type of wasp that lays its eggs in individual plant and leaf stems, causing the plant to create a swollen growth around the egg?
Which type of wasp is known for creating clay and mud containers to house its offspring, and has been responsible for several major airline crashes?
What is the estimated number of babies a termite queen can lay in her lifetime?

title: The science of hearing - Douglas L. Oliver

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main parts of the auditory system?
What is the primary function of the ear in the auditory system?

options.label: B
options.text: To convert sound energy into neural signals

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the eardrum and the tiny bones of the middle ear?

options.label: B
options.text: To convert sound waves into pressure waves in the fluid of the cochlea

options.label: C
options.text: To detect vibrations in the air

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the volume of sound

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the surface that runs the length of the cochlea and is lined with hair cells?
How do hair cells in the cochlea respond to sound vibrations?

options.label: B
options.text: They vibrate at a fixed frequency

options.label: C
options.text: They move with the vibrations of the cochlear fluid and the basilar membrane

multiple-choice.question: How does the brain determine the location of a sound in space?

options.label: A
options.text: By analyzing the intensity of the sound

options.label: B
options.text: By comparing the sounds coming into the two ears

options.label: C
options.text: By detecting the frequency of the sound

options.label: D
options.text: By measuring the distance from the sound source

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the condition where the brain perceives a sound when there is no actual sound present?
What is the primary cause of hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Exposure to loud noises and some drugs

multiple-choice.question: How do the tiny bones in the ear respond to sound vibrations in a person with osteosclerosis?

options.label: C
options.text: They are frozen and do not vibrate

options.label: D
options.text: They are damaged and cannot vibrate

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the auditory system's processing of sound information?

options.label: B
options.text: Precisely tuned electrical impulses that distinguish different sounds

options.label: C
options.text: A mixture of sound and light waves

options.label: D
options.text: A random pattern of neural signals

title: Did the Amazons really exist? - Adrienne Mayor

multiple-choice.question: According to ancient stories, what legendary war did the Amazons fight in?
In ancient Greek art and literature, how were the Amazons typically depicted?

options.label: C
options.text: As daring and desirable, but also terrifying and deadly

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the vast territory where ancient historians located the Amazon homeland?
What was unique about the Scythian culture that allowed for a form of equality between men and women?

options.label: C
options.text: Their nomadic lifestyle and harsh landscape

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the recent archaeological discoveries in Scythian kurgans?

options.label: A
options.text: They provided evidence of the existence of male Scythian warriors

options.label: B
options.text: They provided evidence of the existence of female Scythian warriors

options.label: C
options.text: They provided evidence of the Scythian's advanced technology

options.label: D
options.text: They provided evidence of the Scythian's written records

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of modern DNA analysis on the skeletons found in Scythian kurgans?

options.label: A
options.text: It revealed that all skeletons belonged to male warriors

options.label: B
options.text: It revealed that about 300 skeletons belonged to females ranging in age from 10 to 45

options.label: C
options.text: It revealed that the skeletons were from a different culture

options.label: D
options.text: It revealed that the skeletons were from a later time period

multiple-choice.question: How did the portrayal of Amazons in Greek art and literature change over time?

options.label: A
options.text: They were initially depicted as realistic and later became more mythological

options.label: B
options.text: They were initially depicted with Greek weapons and armor, but later with bows and battle-axes

options.label: C
options.text: They were initially depicted as weak and submissive, but later as strong and heroic

options.label: D
options.text: They were initially depicted as men, but later as women

multiple-choice.question: What was the reaction of the ancient Greeks to the idea of strong women who gloried in freedom and war?

options.label: A
options.text: They were only drawn to egalitarian ideals

options.label: B
options.text: They were only opposed to the idea

options.label: C
options.text: They had mixed feelings about the idea

options.label: D
options.text: They were indifferent to the idea

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the Amazon myth in male-dominated classical Greece?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a way to reinforce patriarchal values

options.label: B
options.text: It was a way to imagine women and men as equal companions

options.label: C
options.text: It was a way to glorify war and violence

options.label: D
options.text: It was a way to promote trade and commerce

multiple-choice.question: What was the approximate time period during which the Scythian culture flourished?
